text: Hi Janessa! Thank you so much for taking the time to look at my profile and give me this great feedback. I think you may have hit the nail on the head! You get so used to telling other people's stories, you forget how to best tell your own! :stuck_out_tongue:

text:
Hi all,

I'm looking for some advice as I plan to start job-hunting again soon. I'm a writer, and while most of my work is long-form SEO content, I do have some more creative pieces from ads, videos, etc. As I work on my portfolio, I'm struggling with the best way to showcase my work. I feel like there's no visually appealing way to organize written work on a website. I'm also frustrated with the cost of websites, as it feels like a waste of money when I'm not actively job hunting. A couple writers in a Facebook group I'm in said they simply use a folder on Google Drive and share that with potential clients and it has worked out well for them. Another suggested just adding those pieces to my LinkedIn profile.

What would you all suggest? I'm open to jobs in both SEO and traditional advertising, so I'd like to highlight both types of work. For the SEO content, I'd also like to include performance metrics as well. I'm not sure what the best way to organize all that would be. Any advice would be appreciated. I'd especially love to hear from anyone who hires creatives to get your perspective on how you'd feel about getting a Google Drive link for a portfolio rather than a link to a website.

text: For writers, I’m ok if they send me a PDF, an email of samples, a drive link, or have a website--but a steller, beautifully designed online portfolio isn’t a requirement. Im looking at writing quality the most. the sooner I can see that, the more likely i am to talk to them.

elements.text: For writers, I’m ok if they send me a PDF, an email of samples, a drive link, or have a website--but a steller, beautifully designed online portfolio isn’t a requirement. Im looking at writing quality the most. the sooner I can see that, the more likely i am to talk to them.

text: <@U01694YQ3FX> Thank you for sharing this perspective! That's really helpful to hear!

elements.text: Thank you for sharing this perspective! That's really helpful to hear!

text:
I think a personal site professionalizes you in a way that sets you apart from all the other commodity writers.

I also think that, if you have them, focusing on the results of your work matters most. If I'm hiring a writer, I want to see a couple "up and to the right" graphs from their work (whether that be traffic, leads, or some other KPI).

elements.text:

I also think that, if you have them, focusing on the results of your work matters most. If I'm hiring a writer, I want to see a couple "up and to the right" graphs from their work (whether that be traffic, leads, or some other KPI).

text: I agree with Jillian. I recently hired for a content writer role and the quality of the writing is way more important. If you're using it to apply to jobs, I would treat it like a cover letter/resume where you tweak your portfolio for each role. The hiring manager likely won't read every sample, so highlight the most relevant pieces.

elements.text: I agree with Jillian. I recently hired for a content writer role and the quality of the writing is way more important. If you're using it to apply to jobs, I would treat it like a cover letter/resume where you tweak your portfolio for each role. The hiring manager likely won't read every sample, so highlight the most relevant pieces.

text: Not that I disagree with <@UUXMCJQ15>. A jazzy site certainly helps! But if you're trying to go lean...

elements.text: . A jazzy site certainly helps! But if you're trying to go lean...

text: I agree with the responses here saying the quality of writing is way more important! BUT I used to apply to writing jobs (now mostly taking on strategy work instead) but I keep my site up to date just in case. I’ve had people say it made my application stand out. Especially because you can share info about yourself, what you’re looking for, and even testimonials. It’s like a fancy cover letter. Here’s mine in case you’re looking for inspiration: <http://danihenion.com|danihenion.com>

text: <@UNA88V285> Definitely something to consider. What platform do you use for your site? It looks simple and clean--I've struggled to find something that works the way you have yours set up.

elements.text: Definitely something to consider. What platform do you use for your site? It looks simple and clean--I've struggled to find something that works the way you have yours set up.

text: A cool thing one writer did who applied for an open role I was hiring for was to create a quick google slides presentation and highlight a piece of work on each slide with a link to the individual piece. On the slide she listed some facts about the piece, why she wrote it, and the results it drove. Really simple, but I found it way more organized than a google drive folder (though that works too). And...I hired her :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: A cool thing one writer did who applied for an open role I was hiring for was to create a quick google slides presentation and highlight a piece of work on each slide with a link to the individual piece. On the slide she listed some facts about the piece, why she wrote it, and the results it drove. Really simple, but I found it way more organized than a google drive folder (though that works too). And...I hired her

text: I’ve seen  and hired writers who used a variety of different formats, and the one thing that has always stood out to me is less about their format and more about their inclusion of a piece that they’re really proud of — a passion piece of sorts. I love reading writing pieces that don’t necessarily have to do with the role they’re applying for, but they’re really passionate about. I like to see where my writers pull their inspirations from. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I’ve seen  and hired writers who used a variety of different formats, and the one thing that has always stood out to me is less about their format and more about their inclusion of a piece that they’re really proud of — a passion piece of sorts. text: <@U023A4RC1RR> I used a super basic theme in Wordpress but then customized it with a service called elementor. It took a couple of hours of tweaking the layout, writing copy for the pages, pulling together writing samples etc. but now all I have to do is keep it updated and remember to pay for hosting/domain renewal (which I have through Bluehost).

text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: mid (4-7 years of experience)

"Hey everyone,

I work at an agency in a mid-senior role. Since starting at the agency, I've gone above and beyond. These efforts didn't go unnoticed and I received excellent feedback from colleagues across the agency. I've achieved some of the top results for campaigns to date, developed all the department processes, and regularly provide consulting to clients alongside the Directors and VPs. I was promised a promotion to a senior position in my next annual review this July. (I think you know where this is going.)

Due to a recent and poorly-communicated change in the system, anyone who was hired after January 1, 2020 has had their annual reviews moved to next January. I was hired on January 6. I will now have only an "informal chat" this year and the promotion (or any raise) is off the table. Meanwhile, everyone else in my department is still getting annual reviews (and all of them received promotions and raises). I'm happy for them, since it's not a race, but I can't help feeling undervalued. I'd also be annoyed if this had happened to anyone else.

Is this the kind of red flag that can't be ignored? Or should I tough it out and keep my fingers crossed for January? I appreciate your thoughts!"

:thinking_face: Any context on why reviews/raises for hires after that date are on pause? Or any acknowledgement/information from the heads of state at your co about why this is happening and what you can expect them to do to make up for it? I would have a hard time trusting my employers in this situation given that this was a promise and you've proven yourself in the role. How it was communicated might change that.

Do you like the job? Are you growing in it? Is it worth staying for reasons other than salary? If not, gtfo. I'm concerned that this wouldn't pan out in your favor come January. And if it does, there's a clear indicator that it could happen again down the line.

elements.text:
